Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience in Structural and Functional Neural Biology for Undergraduates
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to Michigan State University, located in East Lansing, MI, will support the training of 8 students in a 10-week program during the summers of 2014-2016. The REU program is open to all undergraduate students who are citizens, nationals or permanent residents of the United States. Students trained in the program will gain skills in lab research, develop their critical thinking and problem-solving skills, understand the process of science, and be able to communicate their research results to their peers and the general public. Students will have an opportunity to present their results at a national conference. The REU program provides an experience to students that is typically not available to them at their home institutions. Students from schools with limited opportunities for research and from underrepresented groups are encouraged to apply.

This REU Site program will focus in research on the structure and function of neurons and their circuitry. The program has been designed to enable early undergraduates (freshman and sophomores) to conduct research in their area of interest. Students will have the option of working individually on their own project, or in collaborative pairs under the same research advisor. Each student will have his/her own independent scientific question to investigate. Example projects include the neurobiology of the autonomic/enteric nervous systems, ion channels structure and function, neuronal cytoskeleton, sensory function, neuronal regeneration, and synaptic physiology. Students apply principles of neurobiology to novel, contemporary research projects and gain deeper knowledge in their topical area of research. During the 10-week program, students will participate in activities that enhance their research experience, such as orientation, seminars and workshops, and other organized activities for the group. At the end of the program, students will present their research in a poster and/or oral presentation.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. In addition, an MSU faculty member will conduct an exit interview with program participants. Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. POR.DRECONTENT:
Twenty seven students over three years participated in a program designed to introduce them to scientific research with the goal of preparing them for careers in research in the biological sciences. A ten week summer internship was provided to students at labs at Michigan State University.  These labs studied neuronal structure and function from the pharmacological, anatomical, biochemical or behavioral standpoints. All research labs were funded by Federal research programs, and each lab provided oversight/training of the student by not only a Ph.D. level faculty member, but also by a student either pursuing the Ph.D., or one in a post Ph.D. internship (postdoc).  Research interns all resided in a campus dormitory to allow them to develop a sense of community. They came from schools on both the US Mainland, as well as Puerto Rico. The majority of them had completed only one year of college, and for all of the students, this was their first research experience. For students from Puerto Rico, this also represented their first trip to the US Mainland.

The specific goal of this research experience was to provide research and education on projects related to the function and structure of neurons, the cells which make up the brain, spinal cord, and nerves in the remainder of the body. Students were selected from schools in which opportunities for such research were lacking, and in particular, students from underrepresented minority classes were chosen. The students received not only hands-on research experience in labs at Michigan State University, but also lectures on the function and structure of nerves, an introduction to the fundamentals of research, research ethics, and experience in presenting their research  in both a poster format, and orally in a 15 minute talk to an audience of scientists.

Success of the program was demonstrated by the majority of students taking further research experiences, or successfully applying to graduate programs in the biological or biomedical sciences. Upon evaluation of the program at the end of the summer, student unanimously indicated that the experience 1) increased their knowledge of research; 2) increased their understanding of research; 3) increased their understanding of the function and structure of neurons.  A significant majority of students reported that the experience 1) increased their desire/interest for another research opportunity; and 2) increased their interest in a future career in research.
